subj-group.subject: International Tax Policy, Reform and Innovation

title-group.article-title: CROSS-COUNTRY EVIDENCE ON THE PRELIMINARY EFFECTS OF PATENT BOX REGIMES ON PATENT ACTIVITY AND OWNERSHIP

contrib.aff: Department of Economics, LeBow College of Business, Drexel University, Philadelphia, PA
Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth, Hanover, NH

abstract.p: This paper takes a first step at evaluating whether patent box regimes achieve their primary stated objectives: namely, stimulating domestic innovation and containing (or retaining) mobile patent income in order to limit base erosion. To do this, we estimate whether these policies increase the attractiveness of a country as a location for patenting domestic innovations or as a location for patent ownership. Furthermore, we examine the extent to which patent box regimes influence the prevalence of cross-border relationships between patent owners and inventors on new patent applications, with a particular focus on ownership involving tax havens—an outcome commonly viewed as a consequence of tax planning. We find that despite their lack of nexus requirements, patent box regimes appear to have been relatively successful at achieving their first objective—increasing new patent applications by an average of 3 percent for every percentage point reduction in the tax rate on patent income. We find no evidence of any significant impact of these regimes on deterring outward attribution of patent ownership, nor on attracting ownership of foreign inventions, at least in the short period since they were put in place. Increased patent activity hence appears to be focused on inventions involving co-located domestic inventors and owners.
